title: Batrachomorpha
text:
Batrachomorpha ("frog form") is a name traditionally given to recent and extinct <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a>s that are more closely related to modern amphibians than they are to <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s. It most often includes the extinct groups <a href="Temnospondyli">Temnospondyli</a> and <a href="Lepospondyli">Lepospondyli</a>. The first <a href="tetrapod">tetrapod</a>s were all amphibians in the physiological sense that they laid their eggs in water, and are colloquially sometimes referred to as <a href="labyrinthodont">labyrinthodont</a>s or <a href="stegocephalia">stegocephalia</a>ns. In this scheme, batrachomorphs composed one branch of these early amphibians, while the <a href="Reptiliomorpha">reptiliomorphs</a> composed the other. While the actual phylogeny of the <a href="lissamphibia">modern amphibians</a> is not well understood, their ancestors are descended from one line of batrachomorphs. All other living tetrapods (<a href="reptile">reptile</a>s, <a href="bird">bird</a>s and <a href="mammal">mammal</a>s) are descended from one branch of reptiliomorphs, the <a href="amniotes">amniotes</a>. Amniotes achieved dominance, while all other reptiliomorphs and most batrachomorphs have gone extinct.
Classification.
Etymology.
The name Batrachomorpha was coined by the Swedish <a href="palaeontologist">palaeontologist</a> <a href="Gunnar%20S%C3%A4ve-S%C3%B6derbergh">Gunnar Säve-Söderbergh</a> in 1934 to refer to <a href="Ichthyostega">ichthyostegids</a>, <a href="Temnospondyli">temnospondyls</a>, <a href="Anthracosauria">anthracosaurs</a>, and the <a href="frog">frog</a>s. Säve-Söderbergh held the view that <a href="salamander">salamander</a>s and <a href="caecilian">caecilian</a>s are not related to the other <a href="tetrapod">tetrapod</a>s, but had developed independently from a different group of <a href="Sarcopterygii">lobe-finned fish</a>, the <a href="porolepiformes">porolepiformes</a>. In this view <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a> would be a <a href="biphyletic%20group">biphyletic group</a>, and Batrachomorpha was erected to form a natural group consisting of the "true amphibians" (i.e. <a href="frog">frog</a>s in Säve-Söderberghs view) and their fossil relatives. The <a href="salamanders">salamanders</a> and the <a href="Lepospondyli">Lepospondyli</a> was consigned to "<a href="Urodelomorpha">Urodelomorpha</a>".
<a href="Friedrich%20von%20Huene">Friedrich von Huene</a> adopted it as a superorder of his subclass "Eutetrapoda" (the lower tetrapods exclusive of the <a href="Urodela">urodeles</a>) and included the orders Stegocephalia (here including a number of Labyrinthodonts and <a href="anura%20%28frog%29">anurans</a>). <a href="Erik%20Jarvik">Erik Jarvik</a>, who took over Säve-Söderberghs work and shared his view of the origin of salamanders, used the term more informally, but in a wider sense, to include the ancestral <a href="osteolepiform">osteolepiform</a> fishes.
Though never a majority view, the notion that tetrapods had evolved twice, together with the usage of the term batrachomorpha, lingered until genetic analysis started confirming the <a href="monophyly">monophyly</a> of living amphibians in the 1990s. Jarviks classification is no longer followed, all living amphibians and their fossil relatives now being classified together in the group <a href="Lissamphibia">Lissamphibia</a>.
Phylogenetics.
<a href="Michael%20J.%20Benton">Michael Benton</a> adopted the term Batrachomorpha to include all living <a href="amphibia">amphibia</a>ns and extinct relatives more closely related to amphibians than to <a href="Amniote">amniotes</a>. In his scheme, Batrachomorpha is a superorder of <a href="Amphibia">Amphibia</a>, containing the following subgroups:
The other groups of tetrapods considered more closely related to <a href="amniotes">amniotes</a> are put in the subclass <a href="Reptiliomorpha">Reptiliomorpha</a>.
The phylogenetic relationships of Paleozoic tetrapods have not yet been worked out with certainty, and the validity of Batrachomorpha as a <a href="clade">clade</a> depends on where other amphibians and early amniotes fit on the evolutionary tree. The actual content of Batrachomorpha as cladistically defined is therefore uncertain, and in some <a href="Phylogeny">phylogenies</a> the clade is redundant (e.g. Laurin 1996).
Anatomy.
Batrachomorphs are distinguished by a number of features in the skeleton, including a flat or shallow skull, a fused <a href="skull%20roof">skull roof</a> with no <a href="cranial%20kinesis">cranial kinesis</a>, <a href="Exoccipital%20bone">exoccipital</a>-<a href="Postparietal%20bone">postparietal</a> contact on the <a href="Occipital%20bone">occiput</a>, and four or fewer fingers on the hand.
<a href="Michael%20J.%20Benton">Benton</a> contrasts Batrachomorphs with <a href="Reptiliomorpha">Reptiliomorphs</a>; both are <a href="Crown%20group%23Stem%20groups">stem-based clades</a>; the former constitutes the "amphibian" evolutionary radiation, the latter the contemporary proto-reptilian and early amniote evolution.
In the appendix to <a href="Vertebrate%20Palaeontology%20%28Benton%29">Vertebrate Palaeontology</a>, which combines cladistic and linnaean rankings, Benton has given Batrachomorpha the rank of Subclass in his 2001 edition, Class in the 2004 edition, and Superorder in the 2014 edition.
